Award.AwardTitle: CONFERENCE: Southeastern Regional Yeast Meeting to be held April 12-14, 2019; Atlanta, GA

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The SERYM annual meeting provides a unique opportunity for yeast researchers from states in the Southeastern region of the U.S. to come together to share their preliminary research findings, and discuss new research tools and emerging technologies. Yeasts are an important model for the study of complex molecular, cellular, biochemical and evolutionary processes. The requested NSF support will fund the travel expenses of student participants in an effort to maximize the number of undergraduate and graduate students that can attend this meeting.

Yeast researchers have made significant contributions in areas as diverse as fungal evolution, DNA damage/repair, gene expression, RNA processing, cell cycle progression, chromosome segregation, prion propagation, autophagy, and organelle biogenesis/maintenance.The SERYM 2019 conference organizers are placing particular
emphasis on fostering science discussions during the meeting and promoting exchange of new ideas among participants, with a particular focus to stimulate undergraduate and graduate attendees in making presentations during the meeting and engaging in interactions with more senior scientists. POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Conference project aimed to support the 26th Annual Southeastern Regional Yeast Meeting (SERYM) 2019 hosted by the Georgia Institute of Technology in Atlanta, GA on April 12 to 14, 2019. The goals of this project were to increase the level of participation by trainees at the SERYM 2019, and thus to provide trainees (undergraduate and graduate students in particular) with an open forum, in which to ask questions and discuss with the panelists their perspectives on how to be successful in a career in academia and industry; to stress to trainees the value of collaboration and networking among colleagues, and the importance of obtaining broad exposure to different experimental methodologies in their early careers; to provide a nurturing environment for the presentation of research accomplishments by undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows; and to continue promoting and maximizing student attendance and participation to science conferences.               

The NSF ravel support received was awarded to 20 undergraduate and graduate students to attend the SERYM 2019. The NSF support provided an excellent opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students to participate to the conference. Particularly, the NSF supported attendees were 21% of total attendees, with 25% of women at the meeting. 22.2% of undergraduate participants were those NSF supported; and among the graduate students, those supported by NSF constituted the 42.9% of all graduate students at the conference. There was also a senior high school student who benefitted of the NSF support and could participate at the meeting. Moreover, the NSF support allowed numerous students from a small college, like Georgia College & State University to participate in SERYM 2019. Some of the best talks and poster presentations of the meeting were given by undergraduate and graduate students supported by the NSF award. In fact, 6 of the 20 NSF awardees also received an excellent presentation award. In sum, the NSF support has made an invaluable contribution to the SERYM 2019 conference.
